div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Baltimore Sun, June 21, 1908
div1.p:
UP TO 12 o'clock last night
the Mosquito Brigade of the
Health Department had
killed 234,678,548,876,234,789,-
432,623 mosquitoes in and about
Baltimore and had wounded,
scared, tracked, trailed, mobbed,
clubbed, crippled, walloped, basti-
nadaed and chased away no fewer
than 3,621,738,541,776,928,316,-
294,444,360,727,663,361,246,818,-
714,928,333,631,647,781,880,721,-
620,228,913,627,366,063,837,145,-
677,829,613,727,163,642,718,621,-
814,364,821,936,821,999,642,721,-
919,001,162,222,388,914,441,621,-
864 more.

THESE figures, which are supplied by
Dr. William N. Hill, commander-
in-chief of the brigade, and certi-
fied under the great seal of the Health
Department by Prof. John William Mont-
gomery Kiger, Auditor-General, may seem
incredibly enormous, but all the same they
are official and, in consequence, accurate.

Anyone who doubts them may verify
them by visiting the battle fields whereon
the brigade has won its most stupendous
victories. Here the carcasses of dead mos-
quitoes are piled mountain high. Near the
3-cent bridge there is a stack as large as a
brewery, and further eastward, along the
romantic shores of Spring Gardens, are
heaps which overshadow the gasworks.
Dr. Hill himself has personally killed more
than 364,721,864,211,731,848 mosquitoes.
NOT A SOLDIER KILLED.

During the numerous engagements and
skirmishes between the skeeters and the
brigade not a soldier has been seriously
wounded. Several admit that they have
been stung, but not one has been compelled
to go to a hospital.

Doctor Hill (who is also a celebrated
singletaxer and free-discussionist) has
probably developed more new methods of
exterminating a tribe of mosquitoes than
any other mosquito warrior in this coun-
try. He is ably surrounded by an army of
roughriding, dashing, bold and gallant
warriors, who know no fear and who fol-
low their general on the battle field with-
out the slightest hesitation.

With spades and picks and cans of kero-
sene as their only weapons, the soldiers
march into dismal swamps, charge with-
out sounding the bugle and do their
bloody work in a few minutes. The attacks
are so well planned that never has one
mosquito been known to escape without
injury.

So expert are the warriors they do not
need any chart or regular line of formation.
They surround the swamp. Each man is
given his instructions. The enemy is then
routed and the battle is over.

Already the good work done by the bri-
gade has been noticed in the suburbs, and
Dr. Hill and his fighters are being highly
commended. According to reports from the
front the brigade has visited every section
in the outlying district and its last report
to Health Commissioner Bosley shows the
above number of fatalities.
MORE MONEY IS NEEDED.

At present the force is not as large as
Generalissimo Hill would like it to be. This
is due entirely to the small appropriation
which was made for it by the Board of Es-
timates. The men in the army want their
pay. If there was money in sight, says Dr.
Hill, he would have no trouble in securing
hundreds of volunteers, but they refuse to
fight just for the glory that is in it.

When the work was begun last year Dr.
Hill had an appropriation of $10,000. With
of swamps and pools in the suburbs and
made hundreds of drains to drain swamps
which were not filled. It was during this
period that mosquitoes were killed by the
billions every day.

In compiling the ordinance of estimates
for this year the board allowed only $5,000
for the work. Undaunted by this only re-
verse in his most successful fighting career,
Dr. Hill resumed his command of the bri-
gade this year as soon as the proclamation
of war was issued by Dr. Bosley.

In a few days he had reorganized his
brigade and was again on the job. Inci-
dentally all the fighters, including the doc-
tor, were put on the city's payroll.

But upon an investigation the General
found that the little pests had been wiped
off of the map in a number of localities.
Most of the swamps which had been drained
had become permanent dry spots and there-
fore unfit for the abode and breeding places
for mosquitoes, and likewise a majority of
the fills were permanent.

Hundreds of the battles did not have to
be fought over again. The first victories
were decisive and, the news was hurriedly
were then sent by wireless for the brigade
to continue the work of filling and drain-
ing swamps, and every day now Dr. Hill
and his men can be seen sneaking through
the alleys and roads of the suburbs look-
ing for the breeding and hiding places of
the enemy.
THE FIGHTING FORCE.

Those in the army this year are:
Col. Francis A. Lloyd, 805 West Frank-
lin street, whose hearing is so good that
he can hear the buzz of a mosquito three
blocks away.
Major Thomas Freeze, 120 Dolphin street,
who pours kerosene on the troubled waters
and keeps account of the number killed.
Capt. Jacob List, of Forest Park, aid to
the General.
Capt. Joseph E. Buxbaum, 927 West
Lombard street, captain of the spade and
pick muskeeters.
Lieut. John C. Lastner, 1723 North Reg-
ester street, world's crack shot with a kero-
sene repeating oil can.
Lieut. R. M. Betz, 417 North Washington
street, official photographer, clerk to the
brigade and general utility man.

pictures have been taken of
the battles by Mr. Betz, and within a few
weeks the bloody scenes and massacres
will be shown on moving-picture machines
in the 5-cent amusement houses on East
Baltimore street.

Although there is no record of a mos-
quito escaping without injury, the mem-
bers of the brigade admit that several
large fellows, apparently heads of the
tribe, have gotten through the lines and
have only been killed after a strenuous
chase. When a mosquito once gets away
General Hill calls for volunteers. Several
of them are usually found among the spec-
tators standing on the banks of the swamp
watching the battle. Of course, the oil can
is not a valuable weapon in a chase, ex-
cept to hurl at the fleeing mosquito.

As soon as the alarm of escape is sound-
ed the entire army is commanded to cap-
ture the fugitive dead or alive. With their
picks and spades the soldiers fly over hills
and through dales after the “stinger.”
CHASING THE SKEETER.

Standing near by at the time of the
escape may be several persons who are
resting after a round on the golf links.
With their golf sticks they immediately
join the pursuing force. On goes the
chase. Persons playing tennis are passed,
and when they learn of the escape they
join in with their tennis racquets. A la-
crosse game is next passed, and, of course,
the players drop the ball and, with their
lacrosse sticks, get into the run.

And so it goes. Like a fox, the mos-
quito gains on his pursuers for the first
few miles. But, encouraged by the thrill-
ing commands of Dr. Hill, the army and
the unpaid recruits keep on the chase.
Realizing the damage that can be done to
the community by the settlement of even
one mosquito, everybody gladly aids in
capturing the pest.

Boys with crab nets, washerwomen with
washbaskets, county police on horseback
and farmers with rakes and hoes join in.
Sometimes they collide and roll down the
hills. But “Forward!” is the command,
and they keep going. Frequently they are
compelled to wade and swim across peace-
ful brooks. But this is all in the game.

Ah! the chase is nearly at an end. Col.
Frank Lloyd, with his remarkable hear-
ing, reports that the mosquito is gasping
for breath, and that if he is not overtaken
within the next mile he will fall exhaust-
ed. The “buzzer” is seen to look back at
his pursuers, and upon his face Dr. Hill
sees the look of despair.

This makes the Doctor encourage his
army on. It now consists of about 50 peo-
ple, scattered for several squares back.
The cops on horseback are near the head
of the procession, for they know that if
they capture the “stinger” they will be
given medals of honor by the County Com-
missioners. The boys with the crab nets
get almost within reaching distance of
the mosquito. They dive, but miss. La-
crosse sticks and tennis racquets, oil cans
picks, baskets, shovels, spades and rocks
fly at its head.

Poor little fellow! Realizing that the
end is near at hand and that if caught he
will not be killed by a hard slap, but
crushed under the foot of Dr. Hill, he
spies a brick wall and then and there
dashes out his brains. The pursuers reach
him just as his lifeless body falls on the
ground.
GOOD-BY THE SKEETER!

The remains are viewed by the army and
the volunteers, all of whom are exhausted.
Of course, they are sorry that they did not
have the pleasure of beheading the pest
or sticking his eye out with a pin, or pull-
ing his stinger out. But the result is the
same. It is dead!

Dr. Hill stands by the dead body, ex-
tols his army and thanks the volunteers
for their assistance. The volunteers re-
turn to their respective duties and pleas-
ures, while the army again continues on
the job.

These exhilarating and dare-devil chases
are never officially reported to Dr. Bosley,
but he frequently hears rumors of them
from those who have joined in the chase.
At all times Dr. Hill refuses to be com-
plimented for the good work that he and
his army are doing, but he is a “plugger”
and is always busy.

It may seem incredible to some people,
but if the work is kept up it will be a
matter of but a few years when mosqui-
toes in and about Baltimore will be as
scarce as hens' teeth. Of course, a stray
one may be found here and there, but
upon investigation, it is believed, it will
be found that it got here on a train pass-
ing through New Jersey or was blown in
from Patapsco Neck by a high wind.

When that time comes the Doctor
still be on the job, capturing these
pests.
